results.title: The Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls
results.brief_description: Based on the recently completed, controversial studies of Australian biblical scholar, Dr Barbara Thiering, which explodes miracles and other elements of the New Testament. Did the virgin birth really happen? And did Jesus actually create the miracles…turning water to wine and feeding the 5,000 with two fishes and five loaves? “The Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls” challenges the Gospels and the events they describe - until now believed by billions of Christians as sacrosanct. Jesus Christ is presented as a spiritual and political revolutionary whose mission was to transform Judaism. Shot in Israel, the Middle East and Europe, against a background of conflict in the region, the program is a compelling story of controversial issues both timely and universal. Every person who’s ever heard of Jesus will want to see it… every Christian should.

results.title: The Riddle
results.creator_credit: Helicon Audio Visual, Lower East Side Information and Service Center for Narcotic Addiction, William Jersey and Barbara Connell
results.brief_description: In a pool room in downtown New York, down and outers are playing pool - some are sniffing cocaine and the theme song “Some are going to win, some are going to lose” is playing. This film is about drug addiction with the main story focusing on one particular addict, his habits, his pyschological and physiological state and the doctor who is attempting to rehabilitate him. A poignant story.

results.title: The Rhino War
results.brief_description: In Africa, the war to save the black rhino is reaching a bitter climax. Armed poachers have swept through East Africa slaughtering the rhino for its valuable horn, bringing the animal perilously close to extinction. In an unprecedented conservation measure, Zimbabwe game rangers now guard Africa’s black rhino population with the government’s permission to shoot poachers on sight. Both man and beast are dying in this tragic conflict, the enemies being greed, corruption and ignorance.

results.title: The Rhine: background for social studies
results.brief_description: An overall view of the significant influence of the Rhine River throughout Europe. Traces its historical importance, from its role as a frontier of the Roman Empire to its place as a highway of modern commerce. Studies its effect upon the lives and activities of the people who live near it and upon the nations which have fought to control it.

results.title: The Revolution will not now take place
results.brief_description: Robert Conquest writes and narrates the history of communism from 1917 to 1969, showing that a true Marxist revolution of power to the people has never occurred. A masterly summary of 52 years of political history, this documentary includes a clip from the Halas and Batchelor animated film version of “Animal Farm”, Leon Trotsky reading a speech in English, Leonard Schapiro commenting on Stalin vs Trotsky and archival footage of historical figures such as Lenin, Stalin, Hitler, Churchill, Kruzchev, Fidel Castro, Ho Chi Minh. Stills filmed by Ken Morse.

results.title: The Revealing eye
results.brief_description: Surveys the history of cinematography and microphotography with many examples of the strides that have been taken in these fields. The history of the scientific study of motion through the cine-camera. High-speed, and time-lapse cinematography allied with X-ray and the microscope have made possible the study of movements and subjects which the normal eye cannot see. Experiments from 1890 to 1940, when it was possible to slow down the flight of a bullet so that one is seen tapping a piece of glass and passing through before the glass is shattered. Cinematography from space rockets. The use of colour photography in the schlieren technique.

results.title: The Return of the soldier
results.creator_credit: Brent Walker Film Productions, Barry R Cooper Productions, Skreba Films, Ann Skinner, Simon Relph and Alan Bridges
results.brief_description: It is 1916. A shell-shocked soldier (Alan Bates) is sent home to the tranquillity of his English estate, his beautiful but spoilt wife Kitty (Julie Christie) and adoring cousin (Ann-Margret). But he barely remembers Kitty and can only find happiness with his first love (Glenda Jackson), who is from a lower class and now married to a schoolteacher. Kitty, however, wants him back whatever the cost. Adapted by Hugh Whitemore from the novel by Rebecca West, with music by Richard Rodney Bennett. Also stars Frank Finlay and Ian Holm.
